title: 112_hr1229
content:
The "Putting the Gulf of Mexico Back to Work Act" is cited as the short title. It includes an amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The "Putting the Gulf of Mexico Back to Work Act" includes an amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act regarding drilling permits. The Secretary must require lessees to obtain a permit before drilling any well and a new permit for significantly different well designs, ensuring compliance with safety requirements. The Secretary must decide on issuing a drilling permit within 30 days of receiving an application, with possible extensions of up to two periods of 15 days each. The notice of delay must include specific reasons and a final decision date. If the application is denied, the Secretary must provide clear reasons and details on deficiencies, allowing the applicant to remedy them. If no decision is made within 60 days, the application is deemed approved. Leases for covered applications submitted to the Secretary of the Interior are considered in directed suspension from May 27, 2010, until a final decision is issued. If no decision is made within specific timeframes, the lease is deemed to be in suspension. The term "covered application" refers to an application for a permit to drill under an oil and gas lease on the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. It includes resubmissions of approved permits before May 27, 2010, received by the Secretary after October 12, 2010. SEC. 102. EXTENSION OF CERTAIN OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF LEASES. The term "covered lease" refers to oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico outer Continental Shelf region that were not producing or were suspended as of April 30, 2010, and would expire by December 31, 2011. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to extend these leases. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to extend the term of covered leases in the Gulf of Mexico outer Continental Shelf region by 1 year. This extension is in addition to any suspensions of operations or production granted by the Minerals Management Service or Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement after May 1, 2010. SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS FOR TITLE. The terms "covered civil action" and "covered energy project" are defined in this title as civil actions related to agency actions affecting energy projects in the Gulf of Mexico, specifically leasing of Federal lands for energy exploration and production, excluding disputes over lease obligations. SEC. 202. Exclusive venue for covered civil actions related to energy projects in the Gulf of Mexico is limited to the 5th circuit unless no proper venue is available within that circuit. SEC. 203. Covered civil actions must be filed within 60 days of the final Federal agency action. SEC. 204. Courts must expedite the hearing and determination of covered civil actions. SEC. 205. Standard of review for these actions is specified. SEC. 205. Standard of review in covered civil actions presumes administrative findings are correct and can only be rebutted by preponderance of evidence in the record. SEC. 206. Court can only grant prospective relief if narrowly drawn, minimally intrusive, and necessary to correct legal violations. SEC. 207. Limitation on attorneys' fees. The "Restarting American Offshore Leasing Now Act" prohibits attorneys' fees, expenses, and court costs payment from the Federal Government in covered civil actions. It also mandates the conduct of proposed oil and gas lease sale 216 in the Central Gulf of Mexico. The Secretary of the Interior must conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 216 within 4 months of the enactment of the Act. The Environmental Impact Statements for the 2007-2012 5-Year OCS Plan and Multi-Sale are sufficient for this lease sale. Additionally, there is a requirement to conduct proposed oil and gas lease sale 218 in the Western Gulf of Mexico. The Secretary of the Interior is required to conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 218 within 8 months of the Act's enactment. The Environmental Impact Statements for the 2007-2012 5-Year OCS Plan and Multi-Sale satisfy the National Environmental Policy Act requirements. Additionally, there is a mandate to conduct proposed oil and gas Lease Sale 220 offshore Virginia. The Secretary of the Interior must conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 220 within one year of the Act's enactment. Tracts will not be leased if drilling conflicts with military operations. Additionally, there is a requirement to conduct proposed oil and gas Lease Sale 222 in the Central Gulf of Mexico. The Secretary of the Interior is required to conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 222 by June 1, 2012, under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. The Environmental Impact Statements for the 2007-2012 5-Year OCS Plan and Multi-Sale are considered to meet the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. SEC. 306. DEFINITIONS.

(1) The term "Environmental Impact Statement for the 2007-2012 5 Year OCS Plan" refers to the Final Environmental Impact Statement for Outer Continental Shelf Oil and Gas Leasing Program: 2007-2012 (April 2007) by the Secretary of the Interior.

(2) The term "Multi-Sale Environmental Impact Statement" refers to the Environmental Impact Statement for Proposed Western Gulf of Mexico OCS Oil and Gas Lease Sales 204, 207, 210, 215, and 218, and Proposed Central Gulf of Mexico OCS Oil and Gas Lease Sales 205, 206, 208, 213, 216, and 222 (September 2008) by the Secretary of the Interior.
